questions.text: In a neonatal intensive care unit at a research-focused hospital in India, a preterm newborn is admitted with signs of respiratory distress. The baby's mother had a complicated pregnancy, which led to early labor. The neonatologist considers the biochemical aspects that could be contributing to the baby's condition, specifically focusing on the surfactant composition in the baby’s lungs. A deficiency in one of the surfactant components is suspected. Which lipid component could be deficient in this preterm newborn, contributing to respiratory distress?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dipalmitoyl phosphatidyl choline

 

Option B:

 

  • The major lipid of lung surfactant is produced by type II alveolar cells.
  • Surfactant reduces surface tension of the aqueous layer of lung and prevents collapse of lung alveoli.
  • Constituents of surfactants: Dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine (DPPC) or dipalmitoyl lecithin (DPL), phosphatidyl glycerol, cholesterol and surfactant proteins A, B and C.
  • During fetal life, lung synthesizes sphingomyelin before 28th week of GA & when fetus matures, more lecithin is produced.
  • The lecithin-sphingomyelin (LS) ratio of amniotic fluid is an index of fetal maturity.
  • If the ratio is 2, it indicates full lung maturity.
  • Premature infants have a higher incidence of RDS because the immature lungs do not synthesize enough DPL.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Cardiolipin: or Di phosphatidylglycerol is a major lipid of mitochondrial membrane and extracted from myocardium. Decreased cardiolipin level results in mitochondrial dysfunction, heart failure, hypothyroidism, and myopathies.

 

Option C: Phosphatidyl ethanolamine: or Cephalin is found in bio membranes and possess amphipathic properties.

 

Option D: Phosphatidyl inositol: or PIP2 is present in bio membranes and plays important role in mediation of hormone action on bio membranes and also acts as a second messenger.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine (DPPC) is the major component of lung surfactant, which reduces surface tension in the alveoli, preventing collapse during exhalation. In preterm babies, surfactant production can be insufficient, leading to respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).

 

Ref: Harper 30/e :  p 216 , Lippincott 7/e : P 204

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with abetalipoproteinemia presents with an abnormal blood picture showing acanthocytes, alongside symptoms of hyperkeratosis, acrodermatitis, and hypercholesterolemia. Considering the pathophysiology of abetalipoproteinemia and the patient's symptoms, the abnormal red cell morphology and associated clinical manifestations are most likely due to the malabsorption of which essential nutrient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Linoleic acid

 

Option D:

 

  • The genetic defect might result in malabsorption of two fatty acids given in the options, but only linoleic acid is strictly essential in the diet (EFA).
  • Linoleic acid and linolenic acid cannot be synthesized in the body and have to be provided only in the food, so they are essential fatty acids.
  • Arachidonic acid can be formed from linoleic acid, if the dietary supply of it is sufficient.

 

ABETALIPOPROTEINEMIA:

 

  • All apo-B containing lipoproteins are decreased due to defect in microsomal triglyceride transfer protein → TAG is not incorporated into VLDL and chylomicrons → absence of LDL and no absorption of Fat-soluble vitamins (causing mental and physical retardation).
  • Low Serum triglycerides, cholesterol and phospholipids.
  • Blindness due to degenerative changes in retina.
  • Erythrocytes have spiny projections (acanthocytes).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Ascorbic acid and (B) Folic acid: Absorption of water-soluble vitamins such as ascorbate and folate are not affected.

 

Option C: Arachidonic acid: Due to the genetic defect, malabsorption of arachidonic acid is also affected but it’s not an EFA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Abetalipoproteinemia is a disorder characterized by the malabsorption and deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins and essential fatty acids, due to the inability to properly synthesize and secrete apolipoprotein B-containing lipoproteins.

 

Linoleic acid is a polyunsaturated fatty acid crucial for maintaining membrane integrity and function, including that of red blood cells. The deficiency in linoleic acid disrupts normal membrane structure, leading to the formation of acanthocytes.

 

Ref: Lippincott 6/e: p 182, 363.

questions.text: A medical researcher is exploring the immunological properties of different phospholipids. During a study designed to understand the role of phospholipids in autoimmune disorders, they isolate various phospholipids from cell membranes and assess their potential antigenic properties. Which of the following phospholipids possesses antigenic properties?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cardiolipin

 

Option B:

 

  • It is the major lipid of Inner Mitochondrial Membranes and is the only Phospholipid which possesses antigenicity.
  • It is recognized by antibodies raised against Treponema pallidum, which causes syphilis.
  • Decreased levels of cardiolipin or alteration in its structure or metabolism cause mitochondrial dysfunction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Plasmalogens are found in bio membranes in brain and muscle.

 

Option C: Phosphatidylinositol acts as a second messenger and plays a vital role in the mediation of hormone action on bio membranes.

 

Option D: Dipalmitoyl Lecithin / Di Palmitoyl Phosphatidyl Choline is the most abundant phospholipid of cell membrane, largest body store of choline and a major constituent of lung surfactant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiolipin is a phospholipid that has antigenic properties and can be involved in autoimmune responses, such as in the case of anti-phospholipid syndrome. It is commonly associated with syphilis, where it is the reactive agent in the Wassermann test, and with lupus, where it is targeted by anti-cardiolipin antibodies.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 108

questions.text: Based on the schematic of various lipid structures as shown in below image, which structure(s) do emulsified lipids adopt prior to hydrolysis during digestion?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Structure E   

 

Option D:

 

Structure E represents a micelle, which is the structure that emulsified lipids form prior to hydrolysis during digestion. Micelles are essential for the solubilization of lipids in the aqueous environment of the intestine and facilitate the action of lipases.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Structures A and C show lipid bilayers and liposomes, respectively, which are not the forms lipids take prior to hydrolysis in the digestive tract.

 

Option B: Structure B shows vesicles, which are involved in cellular transport but not in the initial stages of lipid digestion.

 

Option C: Structure D shows a lipid monolayer, which is more typical of lung surfactants or the tear film than of intestinal lipid digestion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • During digestion, lipid droplets are emulsified by phospholipids and bile acids in the gut by their detergent action.
  • In micelle hydrophilic glycerol molecules form the outside with hydrophobic fatty acid chains on the inside.
  • Thereby increasing the surface area for the action of hydrolytic lipases

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 479,480

questions.text: Match the following enzymes with the pathway they are involved in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c

 

Option A:

 

Explanation:

 

  1. HMG CoA Reductase is a key enzyme in the biosynthesis of cholesterol, catalyzing the conversion of HMG-CoA to mevalonate, a rate-limiting step in cholesterol synthesis. Hence, 1-b is correct.

  2. 7-alpha-hydroxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme in the formation of bile acids from cholesterol. It catalyzes the introduction of a hydroxyl group at the 7th position of the steroid nucleus of cholesterol, which is the first step in the classical pathway of bile acid synthesis. Thus, 2-a is correct.

  3. Thiophorase, also known as succinyl-CoA:3-ketoacid coenzyme A transferase (SCOT), is involved in ketolysis, particularly in the utilization of ketone bodies by the tissues outside the liver, converting acetoacetate into acetoacetyl-CoA. Therefore, 3-d is accurate.

  4. Carnitine acyl transferase I is a crucial enzyme in the beta-oxidation of fatty acids. It facilitates the transport of fatty acids into the mitochondria for oxidation by converting them into their acyl-carnitine derivatives, which can cross the mitochondrial membrane. Hence, 4-c is correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 172,178

choices.text: Increase with the increase in degree of unsaturation
Decrease with the increase in degree of unsaturation
Increase with the increase in molecular weight
Increase with the decrease in molecular weight

questions.text: What is the relationship between the iodine number of a fat molecule and its degree of unsaturation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increase with the increase in degree of unsaturation

 

Option A:

 

The iodine number of a fat is a measure of the number of double bonds present, which is an indicator of unsaturation. The more double bonds a fat molecule has, the more iodine it can absorb, and thus, the higher its iodine number will be.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Incorrect because the iodine number actually increases with the degree of unsaturation.

 

Option C: Incorrect as the molecular weight does not directly affect the iodine number; it's the unsaturation that matters.

 

Option D: Incorrect because the change in molecular weight does not necessarily correlate with iodine absorption; the focus should be on unsaturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Iodine number of a fat is defined as the number of grams of iodine taken up by 100 grams of fat.
  • It is an index of the degree of unsaturation and directly proportional to the content of unsaturated fatty acids.
  • So higher the iodine number, higher is the degree of unsaturation,
  • e.g., Iodine number of butter : 28,  sunflower oil:130.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 104

choices.text: Excretion of bile salts & Conjugation of bile acids
The excretion of fats in the feces

questions.text: A 55-year-old obese woman visits her primary care physician complaining of recurrent episodes of mild epigastric pain and vomiting, particularly after consuming fatty meals. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the epigastric region. Given the patient's symptoms and risk factors, the physician suspects a biliary tract disorder and refers her for an abdominal ultrasound, which confirms the presence of gallstones in the gallbladder. One of the stones appears to be lodged in the upper part of the bile duct, potentially impacting bile flow and digestion. A gallstone obstructing the upper part of the bile duct would most likely lead to an increase in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The excretion of excess fats in the feces

 

Option C:

 

An obstruction in the bile duct by a gallstone can lead to a decrease in the flow of bile into the intestine. Since bile is essential for the emulsification and absorption of dietary fats, a blockage can result in malabsorption of fats. This malabsorption, in turn, leads to an increase in the excretion of fats in the feces, a condition known as steatorrhea.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Formation of chylomicrons: Chylomicrons are formed in the intestinal cells to transport absorbed fats, including triglycerides, cholesterol, and fat-soluble vitamins, from the intestines to other parts of the body. Bile duct obstruction does not directly affect chylomicron formation but impacts fat absorption, which indirectly could affect chylomicron content.

 

Option B: Excretion of bile salts & Conjugation of bile acids: Bile salts and bile acids are involved in the emulsification of fats and are recycled via the enterohepatic circulation. While obstruction can lead to decreased bile flow into the intestine, it primarily affects fat absorption rather than the excretion or conjugation of bile components.

 

Option D: Recycling of bile salts: The recycling of bile salts is part of the enterohepatic circulation, where bile salts are reabsorbed from the intestines and returned to the liver. A blockage in the bile duct might disrupt this recycling process, but the more immediate effect is on fat absorption and fecal fat excretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gallstones are made up of cholesterol, calcium bilirubinate and bile salts.
  • All the above given details such as female, middle-aged, and overweight shows the patient has gallbladder disease.
  • FUNCTION: The gallbladder stores bile salts produced by the liver and when it is contracted by the entry of food → bile salts travel through the bile duct to the duodenum → causes emulsification of fats, thereby helping in digestion of fat.
  • When the solutes in the gallbladder precipitate, they form gallstones.
  • Patients may have pain from the gallstones, usually after a fatty meal. The pain sites are epigastric or right upper quadrant, which radiates to the right shoulder. Also, cholecystitis and pancreatitis (stones → bile duct -> obstruct biliary flow → jaundice or irritate the pancreas).
  • Obstruction of bile duct → bile salts cannot enter the digestive tract → recycling and excretion of bile salts, digestion of fats and formation of chylomicrons are decreased →  fats in the feces are increased (Steatorrhea).

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 255-257, 149-150.

questions.text: Identify the given diagram:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Liposome

 

Option A:

 

  • Liposomes are microscopic spherical vesicles formed when phospholipids are mixed in water under special conditions, they arrange themselves to form a bilayer membrane which encloses some of the water in a phospholipid sphere.
  • Unilamellar or multilamellar liposomes may be formed.
  • They act as carriers for drugs, proteins, enzymes, genes, etc. which may be encapsulated by the liposomes and taken to target organs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Lipid Bilayer: The self-assembly of phospholipids molecules into monolayers with the polar heads in one direction and the nonpolar tails in the opposite direction to form bilayers. They act as detergents, emulsifying agents, and pulmonary surfactants etc.

 

 

Option C: Micelle: These are molecular aggregates formed when phospholipids are distributed in water and their hydrophobic parts keep away from water and are involved in solubilization of lipids in aqueous media and in digestion and absorption of lipids.

 

Option D: Aquasome: These are nanoparticulate carrier systems with three layered self-assembled structures comprise the central solid nanocrystalline core coated with polyhydroxy oligomers onto which biochemically active molecules are adsorbed. They act as a carrier system for delivery of insulin, haemoglobin and various antigens etc.

 

Educational objective:

 

Liposome, which is a spherical vesicle having at least one lipid bilayer. The liposome can be used to deliver drugs or genetic material into a cell. It is composed of phospholipids that form a bilayer similar to the cell membrane with an aqueous interior; this structure is ideal for encapsulating aqueous solutions of hydrophilic drugs.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 105.

questions.text: A neonatologist is called to attend to a 36-week preterm neonate experiencing respiratory distress. The baby shows increased respiratory rate, chest wall retraction, cyanosis, pallor, and his condition deteriorates despite oxygen support. The Chest X ray findings is shown below. Which of the following lecithin-sphingomyelin (LS) ratios in amniotic fluid indicates full lung maturity?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2

 

Option D:

 

  • Major lipid of lung surfactant produced by type II alveolar cells.
  • Surfactant → reduces surface tension of the aqueous layer of lung → prevents collapse of lung alveoli.
  • It is composed of Dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine (DPPC) or dipalmitoyl lecithin (DPL), phosphatidyl glycerol, cholesterol and surfactant proteins A, B and C.
  • During fetal life, the lung synthesizes sphingomyelin before 28th week of GA & when the fetus matures, more lecithin is produced.
  • The lecithin-sphingomyelin (LS) ratio of amniotic fluid is an index of fetal maturity and if ratio is 2, it indicates full lung maturity.
  • Premature infants have a higher incidence of RDS because the immature lungs do not synthesize enough DPL.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: An LS ratio of 0.5 indicates significant immaturity of the lungs.

 

Option B: An LS ratio of 1 is borderline; however, it does not assure full lung maturity.

 

Option C: An LS ratio of 1.5 is approaching maturity but is not the threshold for full maturity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An LS ratio of 2 or greater in amniotic fluid is generally considered indicative of full lung maturity. This suggests sufficient surfactant production to lower surface tension in the alveoli, reducing the risk of alveolar collapse and RDS.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 106.

choices.text: PUFA is essential for membrane structure
Biologically arachidonic acid is essential to life
Hydrogenated vegetable oils contain trans fatty acid
Naturally occurring unsaturated FA exist as trans isomer

questions.text: FALSE statement about fatty acid:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Naturally occurring unsaturated FA exist as trans isomer

 

Option D:

 

The false statement is that naturally occurring unsaturated fatty acids typically exist in the trans isomer form. In fact, most unsaturated fatty acids in nature are in the cis configuration. The cis configuration causes a bend in the fatty acid chain, which prevents the molecules from packing tightly together, thus contributing to the fluidity of cell membranes. Trans fatty acids, which can be formed during the industrial process of hydrogenation or occasionally found in small amounts in some animal fats, have a straighter shape that allows them to pack more closely together, resembling the behavior of saturated fats.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: PUFA is essential for membrane structure: This is true. Polyunsaturated fatty acids are crucial for maintaining the fluidity and functionality of cell membranes.

 

Option B: Biologically arachidonic acid is essential to life: This is true. Arachidonic acid is important for the synthesis of eicosanoids, which are involved in various physiological functions, including inflammation and immune response.

 

Option C: Hydrogenated vegetable oils contain trans fatty acid: This is true. The process of hydrogenating vegetable oils, which is used to convert them into semi-solid forms for use in various food products, often results in the formation of trans fatty acids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Most naturally occurring unsaturated fatty acids are in the cis configuration, which impacts cell membrane fluidity and overall metabolic health, as opposed to trans fatty acids that are largely produced industrially and have negative health implications.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p241

questions.text: The eukaryotic plasma membrane is a dynamic structure crucial for maintaining the integrity of the cell, facilitating communication, and transporting substances into and out of the cell. Its composition is diverse, including various types of molecules that contribute to its fluid mosaic model. Among the following options, which one is NOT typically found as a component of the eukaryotic plasma membrane?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Triglycerides

 

Option B:

 

Triglycerides are not a typical component of the eukaryotic plasma membrane. The plasma membrane is mainly composed of a phospholipid bilayer, in which the phospholipids (such as lecithin) have a glycerol backbone, two fatty acid tails, and a phosphate group with various head groups. Triglycerides, on the other hand, consist of a glycerol backbone and three fatty acid tails and are primarily involved in energy storage in adipose cells, not in forming the structure of plasma membranes.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Carbohydrates: Carbohydrates are typically attached to proteins (glycoproteins) or lipids (glycolipids) on the extracellular surface of the plasma membrane, playing key roles in cell recognition, signaling, and adhesion.

 

Option C: Lecithin: Lecithin (a type of phospholipid) is a major component of the plasma membrane, contributing to its fluidity and structural integrity.

 

Option D: Cholesterol: Cholesterol is interspersed among the phospholipids of the plasma membrane, where it serves to modulate fluidity and mechanical stability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Plasma membranes are complex structures made of Lipids, Proteins, and Carbohydrates.
  • The major lipids seen in our mammalian membranes include phospholipids, glycosphingolipids, and cholesterol.
  • Major phospholipids present in membranes are phosphoglycerides, among which lecithin is most abundantly seen.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p478

questions.text: In the context of cell signaling pathways, second messengers play a crucial role in amplifying and propagating signals within the cell. These molecules are often produced as a result of receptor activation on the cell surface. From which of the following molecules is a well-known second messenger commonly produced?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phosphatidylinositol

 

Option A:

 

Phosphatidylinositol, specifically phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2), is a precursor for the second messengers inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG) in the phosphoinositide signaling pathway. Upon activation of certain G-protein coupled receptors, the enzyme phospholipase C (PLC) is activated, which then cleaves PIP2 to generate IP3 and DAG. IP3 diffuses through the cytosol to the endoplasmic reticulum, where it binds to and opens calcium channels, thereby increasing intracellular calcium levels and activating downstream signaling cascades. DAG remains in the plasma membrane and, together with calcium, activates protein kinase C (PKC), leading to further cellular responses.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Phosphatidyl ethanolamine: While an important phospholipid in the membrane, it is not directly involved in the generation of second messengers.

 

Option C: Phosphatidylcholine: It can be involved in signaling pathways, for instance, through its breakdown by phospholipase D to produce phosphatidic acid, but it is not the classical route for second messenger production like phosphatidylinositol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phosphatidylinositol

 

  • It is present in the cell membrane
  • Plays an important role in cell signalling, membrane trafficking and as a precursor of second messenger in hormonal pathways.
  • Diacylglycerol and Inositol Trisphosphate IP3 act as second messengers.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p216

questions.text: Cell membranes are composed of various lipids that contribute to their structural integrity and functionality. Among these, glycolipids play a special role in cell recognition, signalling, and interaction with the extracellular environment. Based on your understanding of membrane lipids, which of the following options is classified as a glycolipid?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cerebroside

 

Option A:

 

Cerebrosides are a type of glycolipid that consist of a ceramide backbone linked to a single sugar molecule, either glucose or galactose. They are primarily found in the outer layer of the plasma membrane and are abundant in the myelin sheath of nerve cells. Glycolipids like cerebrosides are involved in cell recognition, cell signaling, and serve as markers for cellular interactions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Plasmalogen: Plasmalogens are a type of phospholipid characterized by the presence of an ether bond at the sn-1 position of the glycerol backbone, not a glycolipid.

 

Option C: Sphingomyelin: Sphingomyelin is a type of sphingophospholipid that contains phosphocholine or phosphoethanolamine as its head group. It is not classified as a glycolipid because it lacks a sugar moiety.

 

Option D: Lecithin: Lecithin, also known as phosphatidylcholine, is a phospholipid that is a major component of cell membranes but does not contain a sugar group, thus not a glycolipid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycolipids or Glycosphingolipids include Cerebroside, Globoside and Ganglioside.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p218

choices.text: Less free fatty acids are delivered from the expanded adipose tissue to the liver
Decreased insulin levels promote fatty acid synthesis in the liver
Increased Insulin resistance causes increased LPL activity
Reduced clearance of chylomicron and VLDL due to reduced LPL activity

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with poorly controlled type 2 diabetes reports fatigue and difficulty losing weight, without classic symptoms of polyuria, polydipsia, or polyphagia. Her blood sugar levels and lipid profile are abnormal. Considering the relationship between obesity and lipid metabolism, which of the following statements is accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Reduced clearance of chylomicron and VLDL due to reduced LPL activity

 

Option D:

 

  • The increase in adipocyte mass and accompanying decrease in insulin sensitivity associated with obesity has multiple effects on lipid metabolism.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Less free fatty acids are delivered from the expanded adipose tissue to the liver: More free fatty acids are delivered from the expanded adipose tissue to the liver

 

Option B: Decreased insulin levels promote fatty acid synthesis in the liver: The increased insulin levels promote fatty acid synthesis in the liver.

 

Option C: Increased Insulin resistance causes increased LPL activity: Increased Insulin resistance causes reduced LPL activity which causes reduced clearance of chylomicron and VLDL →  results in hypertriglyceridemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obesity, particularly with insulin resistance, often leads to decreased activity of the enzyme lipoprotein lipase (LPL), impairing fat clearance from the blood and contributing to dyslipidemia. Contrary to other possibilities, this condition typically results in increased free fatty acids to the liver and does not promote fatty acid synthesis due to decreased, not increased, LPL activity.

 

Ref: Lippincott 7/e: 351-355.

questions.text: Following a substantial meal, an individual's metabolic processes adjust to manage the influx of nutrients. In adipocytes, specifically, one enzyme becomes particularly active to facilitate the storage of excess energy. Which enzyme is primarily activated in adipocytes postprandially?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phosphatidate phosphatase

 

Option D:

 

  • This enzyme converts phosphatidic acid to DAG during synthesis of triacylglycerol (TAG).
  • The function of adipose tissue is the storage of FA’s as TAGs in fed state and the release of fatty acids during times of fasting or starvation.
  • Fatty acids taken in by adipocytes are stored by esterification to glycerol-3-phosphate (derived almost entirely from the glycolytic intermediate DHAP through the action of glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Glycolytic enzymes are active in adipocytes during triglyceride synthesis, but those of glycogen degradation (low levels in adipocytes) and gluconeogenesis (glucose-6-phosphatase) are not.

 

Option B: It is not present much in adipocytes, so that glycerol released during lipolysis is not used to reesterify the fatty acids being freed.


Option C: It is turned on by phosphorylation by a cyclic AMP-dependent protein kinase following epinephrine stimulation in fasting state.

 

Educational objective:

 

Phosphatidate phosphatase plays a crucial role in adipocytes following a heavy meal by catalyzing the dephosphorylation of phosphatidic acid to diacylglycerol, which is a key step in the synthesis of triacylglycerol (the storage form of fats).

 

Postprandially, when there is an abundance of dietary fats and carbohydrates, the body prioritizes the storage of excess energy as fat in adipocytes, and phosphatidate phosphatase is instrumental in this process.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9 /ed: p 160.

questions.text: Which enzyme is primarily responsible for hydrolyzing stored triacylglycerols in adipose tissue to release fatty acids for energy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hormone sensitive lipase

 

Option D:

 

Hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) plays a crucial role in mobilizing stored fats within adipose tissue. Under the influence of hormonal signals like catecholamines during fasting or exercise, HSL is activated to hydrolyze stored triacylglycerols, releasing free fatty acids and glycerol into the bloodstream for energy use by other tissues.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Pancreatic Lipase: This enzyme functions primarily in the digestive system to break down dietary fats into free fatty acids and monoglycerides, which can then be absorbed by the intestinal mucosa. It is not involved in the mobilization of stored triacylglycerols within adipose tissue.

 

Option B: Lipoprotein Lipase: Found on the surface of endothelial cells lining blood vessels, lipoprotein lipase acts on circulating lipoproteins, such as chylomicrons and VLDL, hydrolyzing their triglycerides to release free fatty acids for uptake by adjacent tissues. It is not directly involved in hydrolyzing stored triacylglycerols within adipocytes.

 

Option C: Lysosomal Lipase: Also known as acid lipase, this enzyme is located within lysosomes and is involved in the intracellular breakdown of lipids, including the hydrolysis of cholesteryl esters and triglycerides within the lysosomes. While it does play a role in lipid metabolism, it is not the primary enzyme for mobilizing stored triacylglycerols in adipose tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hormone sensitive lipase hydrolyze stored TGs in adipose tissue under fasting/starvation conditions.
  • This enzyme is activated by glucagon and inhibited by insulin.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p263

choices.text: Glycocholic acid is a conjugate of cholic acid and glycine
7α-hydroxylase is the regulatory enzyme in bile salt synthesis
7α-hydroxy cholesterol is a precursor of both chenodeoxycholate and cholate
Taurochenodeoxy cholate is derived from cholic acid

questions.text: A pediatric gastroenterologist is assessing a child with liver failure. As part of the diagnostic workup, serum bile acid analysis is performed to evaluate liver function and bile acid metabolism. The gastroenterologist is explaining to the medical trainees that understanding bile salt synthesis is crucial for interpreting these results. She poses a question to the trainees to identify the incorrect statement regarding the synthesis of bile salts:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Taurochenodeoxycholate is derived from cholic acid 

 

Option D:

 

  • The primary bile acids are cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid synthesized in the liver from cholesterol and are conjugated with either glycine or taurine to form Glycocholic acid, taurocholic acid, lycol chenodeoxy cholic acid and tauro chenodeoxy cholic acid.
  • 7α-hydroxylation of cholesterol is the regulatory step in the biosynthesis of bile acids and is catalysed by 7 alpha-hydroxylase.
  • 7α-hydroxycholestrol is a precursor of both chenodeoxy cholate and cholate.
  • Secondary bile acids:  Cholic acid is converted to deoxycholic acid and chenodeoxy cholic acid to lithocholic acid.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Glycocholic acid is a conjugate of cholic acid and glycine: This is correct. Glycocholic acid is indeed a bile salt formed by the conjugation of cholic acid with glycine.

 

Option B: 7α-hydroxylase is the regulatory enzyme in bile salt synthesis: True, 7α-hydroxylase is a key enzyme in the synthesis of bile acids, which is the initial and rate-limiting step in the bile acid synthesis pathway from cholesterol.

 

Option C: 7α-hydroxy cholesterol is a precursor of both chenodeoxycholate and cholate: This is also true. 7α-hydroxy cholesterol is an intermediate in the synthesis pathway of both cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid, which are primary bile acids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Taurochenodeoxycholate is incorrectly stated as being derived from cholic acid. In reality, taurochenodeoxycholate is a conjugate of chenodeoxycholic acid with taurine, not cholic acid. Bile salts are formed by the conjugation of bile acids (like cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid) with amino acids such as glycine or taurine, which enhances their solubility and function in the emulsification of lipids.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 273, Vasudevan 9/e: p 231

questions.text:
A 52-years-old man weighing 90 kg doing sedentary work denies any health issues.

 

Routine blood test results were all normal except for plasma total cholesterol of 288 mg/dl. He was not willing to take treatment for his hypercholesterolemia. So, analysis of his 1-day dietary chart comes as follows:

 

 

So, which of the following can be decreased from the diet to reduce the high plasma cholesterol levels?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Saturated fat

 

Option D:

 

  • The intake of saturated fat most likely influences plasma cholesterol in the given diet.
  • The patient is consuming a high-calorie, high-fat diet with 35-40% of the fat as saturated fat.
  • The most important dietary recommendations are reducing the total calorie intake, substitute MUFA & PUFA for saturated fats and also increase dietary fibre.
  • Though a decrease in dietary cholesterol can have effects on the lipid profile, it is always a secondary option to saturated fat.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Carbohydrate: It provides almost 60–65% of total calories and dietary fibre, which improves bowel motility, prevents constipation, and decreases the reabsorption of bile acids thereby reducing the cholesterol level and improves glucose tolerance.

 

Option B: Cholesterol: It is always advised to reduce that dietary intake of cholesterol due to its atherogenic effect and the risk of developing coronary artery disease.


Option C: Unsaturated fat: Saturated fats increase the serum cholesterol and unsaturated fats (vegetable oils and fish oils) reduces it. Especially PUFAs causes esterification and excretion of cholesterol, thereby reducing the cholesterol level in blood. Hence they are antiatherogenic and always preferred in the diet.

 

Educational objective:

 

A reduction in saturated fat intake is often recommended to lower plasma cholesterol levels. Saturated fats can increase low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol, which is a major risk factor for coronary artery disease. The patient's diet, with 78g of saturated fat, significantly exceeds the American Heart Association's recommendation of 5-6% of total daily calories from saturated fat.

 

Ref: Lippincott 7/e: P 360-364.

questions.text: A 30-year-old obese woman started with Tab. Orlistat, as she fails to follow the lifestyle modifications advised by her physician. Which of the following steps of digestion and absorption of fats is directly inhibited by Orlistat?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pancreatic and gastric lipase

 

Option C:

 

  • Orlistat inhibits gastric and pancreatic lipases, thus preventing the digestion and absorption of fats.

 

Sequence of events in digestion:

 

  • Triglycerides are emulsified by bile salts → then acted on by lipases.
  • The product of digestion is absorbed → re-esterified/ resynthesis of TAG in the intestinal mucosal cells → TAG is then packed in the chylomicrons → transported to the peripheral cells for utilization.

 

Effect of orlistat:

 

  • Triglycerides are left undigested and unabsorbed → resulting in bulky stools.
  • Orlistat therapy if given for a long time → induce deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Bile salt formation: Bile salts are produced in the liver from cholesterol and play a crucial role in emulsifying fats in the small intestine to aid in their digestion. Orlistat does not directly inhibit bile salt formation; its action is focused on blocking the enzymes that break down fats into absorbable units.

 

Option B: Micelle formation: Micelles are formed in the small intestine and are essential for the absorption of digested fats. They are composed of bile salts, fatty acids, cholesterol, and other lipids. While Orlistat’s action reduces the amount of free fatty acids available for micelle formation (by inhibiting lipase activity), it does not directly inhibit the formation of micelles themselves.

 

Option D: Absorption of Free fatty acids: Orlistat indirectly affects the absorption of free fatty acids by inhibiting their release from dietary fats. However, the drug does not directly inhibit the cellular mechanisms responsible for the absorption of free fatty acids across the intestinal lining.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key takeaway is that Orlistat specifically inhibits the action of pancreatic and gastric lipases, enzymes critical for the breakdown of dietary fats into smaller, absorbable molecules like free fatty acids and monoglycerides. By doing so, it reduces the overall absorption of fats from the diet, aiding in weight management. It does not directly affect bile salt formation, micelle formation, or the absorption mechanism of free fatty acids.

 

Ref: Lippincott 6/e: p 175-177.

choices.text: Amino acids through transamination reactions
Isoprene units through condensation reactions
Fatty acids through elongation processes

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the precursors used in the synthesis of carotenoids?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isoprene units through condensation reactions

 

Option B:

 

Carotenoids are synthesized from isoprene units, which are five-carbon compounds. The synthesis involves the condensation of these units to form the 40-carbon skeleton that characterizes carotenoids. Specifically, eight isoprene units are condensed to form the carotenoid structure, through the tail-to-tail linkage of two geranylgeranyl pyrophosphate (GGPP) molecules, each comprising four isoprene units.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Amino acids are not directly involved in the synthesis of carotenoids. While amino acids are crucial for protein synthesis and other metabolic functions, they do not serve as precursors for carotenoid synthesis.

 

Option C: Fatty acids are involved in various metabolic processes, including energy storage and membrane synthesis, but they are not directly converted into carotenoids. The elongation of fatty acids refers to the process of adding carbon units to a fatty acid chain, not the synthesis of carotenoids.

 

Option D: Glucose is a central molecule in energy metabolism, participating in pathways such as glycolysis and the citric acid cycle. However, glucose is not directly used in the synthesis of carotenoids. While some of the intermediates from glucose metabolism might contribute to the pool of precursors for isoprene unit synthesis, glucose itself is not a direct precursor for carotenoids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isoprene units are precursors to many Isoprenoid compounds such as

 

  • Vitamin A
  • Vitamin K
  • Carotenoids
  • Ubiquinone (a component of electron transport chain)
  • Dolichol (a compound involved in glycoprotein synthesis)

 

Ref: Pankaja Naik 6/e: p276.

choices.text: Saturated fat <7 % of total calories

questions.text: A 75-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), who recently underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), is scheduled for a postoperative follow-up visit. During the visit, the cardiologist reviews the patient's postoperative recovery and emphasizes the importance of dietary and lifestyle modifications to manage his CAD and reduce the risk of future cardiac events. The cardiologist outlines several recommendations but also wants to clarify a common misconception about dietary guidelines for patients with a high risk of coronary heart disease. Which of the following dietary goals is NOT typically recommended for patients with a high risk of coronary heart disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dietary cholesterol < 300 mg/day

 

Option C:

 

While mindful consumption of dietary cholesterol is part of a heart-healthy lifestyle, recent guidelines have shifted focus towards reducing saturated and trans fats. The specific limit of <300 mg/day is not emphasized as stringently for CAD patients as managing overall dietary patterns and saturated fat intake.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: LDL cholesterol < 100 mg/dl: This target is recommended for individuals with CAD to reduce the risk of further coronary events. Lowering LDL cholesterol is a key focus in managing CAD because elevated LDL levels are directly linked to an increased risk of atherosclerosis and subsequent heart problems.

 

Option B: Saturated fat <7% of total calories: Reducing saturated fat intake is crucial for individuals with CAD as saturated fats can raise LDL cholesterol levels, contributing to the buildup of plaques in arteries. Limiting saturated fats to less than 7% of total daily calories is part of a heart-healthy diet aimed at reducing cardiovascular risk.

 

Option D: Avoid Alcohol: Moderation in alcohol consumption is generally advised for the general population. For patients with CAD, alcohol should be consumed with caution due to its potential effects on blood pressure, triglyceride levels, and caloric intake. While moderate alcohol intake may have some cardiovascular benefits in certain individuals, avoiding excessive alcohol is crucial, especially for those with CAD or those who have difficulty consuming alcohol in moderation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For managing coronary artery disease, dietary recommendations emphasize reducing saturated fat intake and maintaining LDL cholesterol levels below 100 mg/dl. The strict limit on dietary cholesterol (<300 mg/day) is less emphasized, while moderation in alcohol consumption is advised for overall heart health.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 253.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient visits your clinic for a routine health check-up. During the consultation, she expresses her concern about high cholesterol levels and its implications on her health. She is particularly interested in understanding which substances in her body, related to her health concerns, do not contain cholesterol. Based on this context, which of the following does not have cholesterol?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adrenaline

 

Option C:

 

Adrenaline, also known as epinephrine, is a hormone and a neurotransmitter that does not derive from cholesterol. It is synthesized from the amino acid tyrosine in the adrenal medulla and certain neurons within the central nervous system. Adrenaline is involved in the body's "fight-or-flight" response, increasing heart rate, contracting blood vessels, and dilating air passages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Vitamin D is synthesized from 7-dehydrocholesterol, a derivative of cholesterol, in the skin under the influence of sunlight (UVB radiation).
 

Option B: Estrogen is a steroid hormone that is synthesized from cholesterol. The steroid hormones are all derived from cholesterol and include the sex hormones and those produced by the adrenal cortex.

 

Option D: Progesterone, like estrogen, is a steroid hormone synthesized from cholesterol. It plays a role in the menstrual cycle, pregnancy, and embryogenesis of humans and other species.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Specialized Products formed from Cholesterol includes

 

  • Bile Acids
  • Vitamin D
  • Sex Hormones
  • Corticosteroids

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p267

questions.text: A 3-years-old female child has complaints of chronic diarrhoea with oily stools and failure to thrive. Her mother gave history of breastfeeding for 2 years and had no problems until she was weaned off. Which of the following enzyme is deficient followed by secretin stimulation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pancreatic lipase

 

Option D:

 

  • The patient’s symptoms are consistent with an inability to absorb triglycerides, which would eliminate Cholesterol esterase.
  • Since the patient does not have any problem while on breast-feeding →the most likely enzyme to be deficient is pancreatic lipase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Cholesterol esterase: The patient has inability to absorb triglycerides, which eliminates Cholesterol esterase from consideration.

 

Option B: Lipoprotein lipase and Option C: Hormone sensitive lipase: Neither hormone sensitive lipase nor lipoprotein lipase is a digestive enzyme.

 

Educational objective:

 

Pancreatic lipase deficiency can lead to impaired fat digestion and absorption, resulting in symptoms like chronic diarrhea with oily stools and failure to thrive, particularly becoming evident when dietary fats from solid foods are introduced after weaning off breast milk.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 599.

choices.text: Amorphous cholesterol dehydrate + potassium bilirubinate

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with no significant medical history is referred to a gastroenterologist after experiencing recurrent episodes of intense epigastric pain that often radiates to the right shoulder, especially after meals rich in fat. Her laboratory workup reveals signs of jaundice, and an ultrasound of the abdomen shows cholelithiasis with cholecystitis and concurrent pancreatitis. During the consultation, the gastroenterologist educates the patient on the nature of the gallstones implicated in her condition:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Crystalline cholesterol monohydrate                         

 

Option B:

 

  • Components: cholesterol monohydrate crystals, calcium bilirubinate, and bile salts.
  • Small changes in the composition of bile can result in crystallization of cholesterol as gallstones and it is also formed when the solutes in the gallbladder precipitate
  • Cholesterol stones (80% of gallstones) are usually yellow-green in appearance
  • C/F: pain (epigastric or right upper quadrant and radiating to the right shoulder) from the gallstones, usually after a fatty meal.
  • If the gallbladder becomes inflamed or infected, cholecystitis can result.
  • The stones can also travel through the bile duct and obstruct biliary flow leading to jaundice, or irritate the pancreas and cause pancreatitis.


Other Options:

 

Option A: Amorphous cholesterol monohydrate: Gallstones are typically crystalline, not amorphous, which means they have a defined structure and shape.

 

Option C: Amorphous cholesterol dehydrate + potassium bilirubinate: Cholesterol stones are usually in the form of cholesterol monohydrate, and while bilirubinate can be a component of pigment stones, it is not typically associated with cholesterol stones.

 

Option D: Crystalline Cholesterol dihydrate: Cholesterol gallstones are predominantly made of the monohydrate form, not dihydrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The majority of gallstones are composed of crystalline cholesterol monohydrate. These stones form when there is an imbalance in the composition of bile, leading to the precipitation of cholesterol. Cholesterol gallstones are often associated with obesity, rapid weight loss, or other metabolic conditions and are known to cause symptoms, particularly after the ingestion of fatty foods.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 537

questions.text: A 65-year-old man, recently treated with angioplasty for coronary artery disease (CAD), is being counseled by his cardiologist on discharge. The cardiologist emphasizes the importance of secondary prevention through lifestyle modifications to manage his cardiovascular risk factors. As part of the comprehensive plan, the cardiologist advises the patient on the optimal cholesterol levels he should aim to maintain to reduce the risk of future cardiac events:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Below 200

 

Option D:

 

For patients with coronary artery disease, maintaining a low level of serum cholesterol is critical for reducing the risk of future cardiac events. The American Heart Association recommends that such patients keep their total cholesterol below 200 mg/dl to minimize the risk of atherosclerosis progression and subsequent cardiac complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • In healthy persons, cholesterol level varies from 150 to 200 mg/dL
  • With risk factors - cholesterol level should be kept below 180 mg/dL.
  • Values around 220 mg/dL - moderate risk
  • Values above 240 mg/dL - needs active treatment.

 

Ref: Fundamentals of Clinical Chemistry 6/e p 419, DM Vasudevan 7/e: p 140-141

choices.text: Cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid
Cholic acid and deoxycholic acid
Deoxycholic acid and lithocholic acid

questions.text: Secondary bile acids are:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Deoxycholic acid and lithocholic acid

 

Option C:

 

Secondary bile acids, which include deoxycholic acid and lithocholic acid, are formed by the bacterial action on primary bile acids in the intestine. Primary bile acids, such as cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid, are synthesized in the liver. When they are secreted into the intestine, gut bacteria can modify them to form secondary bile acids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid: These are primary bile acids synthesized in the liver from cholesterol.

 

Option B: Cholic acid and deoxycholic acid: Cholic acid is a primary bile acid, whereas deoxycholic acid is a secondary bile acid.

 

Option D: Lithocholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid: Lithocholic acid is a secondary bile acid, while chenodeoxycholic acid is a primary bile acid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary Bile Acids: Formed in Liver

 

  1. Cholic Acid (Most abundant bile acids in mammals)
  2. Chenodeoxycholic Acid

 

Secondary Bile acids: Formed in Intestine

 

  1. Deoxycholic Acid
  2. Lithocholic Acid

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 232.

questions.text: Bile acids are primarily synthesized from which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cholesterol

 

Option A:

 

Bile acids are synthesized from cholesterol in the liver. This process involves multiple enzymatic steps that convert cholesterol into primary bile acids, such as cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid. These bile acids play a critical role in the digestion and absorption of dietary fats and fat-soluble vitamins in the intestine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Fatty acid: Fatty acids are key components of fats and are involved in various metabolic processes, but they are not the precursors for bile acid synthesis.

 

Option C: Bilirubin: Bilirubin is a breakdown product of heme from hemoglobin in red blood cells. It is excreted in bile but is not a precursor to bile acid synthesis.

 

Option D: Proteins: Proteins serve numerous functions in the body, including acting as enzymes and structural components, but they are not directly involved in the synthesis of bile acids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bile acids are synthesized from cholesterol in liver.
  • Rate limiting enzyme: seven α hydroxylase, Microsomal enzyme: Cyt P450, O2, NADPH, Vit C.

 

Ref: Harper 30/ed ,pg 273
